name: Kate Speer | Mental Health Advocate
bio:
Probably Anxious. Definitely grateful you’re here.
Normalizing serious mental illness recovery one messy, honest day at a time.
NYT + NPR re my work👇

social_posts.post_text:
I talked about having human kids in therapy last night. The waves of overwhelm washed over me in fits of sobs. It’s not talked about enough — having kids while living with serious mental illness. The complexity of having kids without a chronic illness is not discussed adequately so it’s no surprise society doesn’t dare broach the subject.

I keep waking up in the middle of the night with my head racing.
Will my symptoms hurt a child?
Will my condition diminish their understanding of my love?
Am I even up to the challenge of such a blessing?
And if we are blessed with a child who can build a life of their own, will they be bullied in grade school because their mom has a service dog?
Will their story be tarnished by how open I am with mine?
Will their life be entirely, freely theirs or haunted forever by the burden of my illness and past?

These questions dominate my sleepless nights and my days are spent wondering about the actual reality of getting pregnant. My body is a perpetual ticking time bomb — bouts of extreme stress send me straight into a dissociative fugue or worse, a bout of psychosis. The one certainty my care team, Dave and I agree upon is that this beautiful, resilient body of mine is not up to carrying a child and due to the extent of my psychiatric history, I am disqualified from most, if not all forms of adoption. So we find ourselves again and again in the land of surrogacy — a stunning yet downright terrifying proposition.

I don’t have the answers. But today, I show up in my humanity as a beacon of solidarity and I hold close the truth that this pain I feel is a privilege. This pain I feel is a privilege.

I am well enough to consider these things.
I am free enough to explore them.
I have a partner, a house, a job, a community and my two best girls.
I have a life. A whole life that is mine.
That is nothing short of spectacular.
And no matter if I have a human child or not, I will always be a mother.
Yes, this best girl of mine made me a mother.
And even though sometimes it doesn’t quite feel like it amidst the barrage of pregnancy announcements and baby photos, that is more than enough.

WAFFLE HEALTH UPDATE: Waffy had her spinal surgery recheck at Tufts yesterday and according to her surgeon, she is doing “TERRIFICALLY!” 🥳💜👯‍♀️😭🎉

Yes — the incredible Dr. Faissler said he is “thrilled” with her progress and has approved her for controlled walks at gradually increasing distances. Today, we get to go on TWO WHOLE TWENTY MINUTE WALKS TOGETHER!!!! I have never been more excited to walk in the frigid pouring rain!!

For the next month, we will slowly scale these controlled walks and then thereafter, she will start back up with physical therapy and hydrotherapy. At this point, she will also be cleared to see morning friendship!! One more month — we can do it!! 

According to her team, by three months out, she will be a new dog. The truth, of course, is that I don’t need a new dog — I don’t want a new dog — I’ve got the perfect one right here beside me. 

But let me tell you, I’m thrilled — THRILLED — she will FEEL like a new dog. I am overjoyed at it — I’m brimming with tears at the mere thought of it, because that is exactly what this best warrior girl of m
Thank you all for the love, kindness and endless support this past year. I know our channel has been far more solemn and quiet as we weathered this years storms but your acceptance of all our colors as the hurricanes waged on will forever propel us forward and mean more than you know.

WAFFLE STRONG.
with so much love and a dork dance,
@kate_speer

I joined a yoga studio last week
I just got to thinking
What am I doing for me? 
How am I showing up for this own home of mine the way I do for others?

The questions left me grasping
I found myself lost in the truth that I do very little to honor this being of mine right now
I quite simply — live in the name of others

Hellbent to change that — I committed to one of my greatest joys – movement
Packing my schedule like the half marathoner I used to be,
I signed up for inferno weights, gentle yoga classes and pilates to boot
And with snug spandex and a room brimming with other breathing human beings
I began the pursuit of reclamation — 
reclamation of self

It’s been five years since I’ve been in a fitness class
Three since I carved out time for home workouts and trail runs with discipline
And two since I fully relapsed into binge eating disorder - my recent refuge of sorts as the puppy blues, my husband’s burnout and Waffle’s health challenges took hold.

I didn’t recognize my reflection when I arrived at the first class
Scanning the mirror, I just couldn’t find me 

And a week of hot yoga, pilates and HIIT later, I still struggle to find myself within the softness, the wide curves, the 20 or so pounds of self compassion donuts that hug my waist

I wish I could say I’m not ashamed of where I have found myself
I wish I could disregard the hatred my mind spews constantly as I grapple with this new home of mine
I wish I could feel the thin privilege I live every single day as I exist in a body that is only a size 16

For the moment though, 
I can’t seem to tame the contempt
I can’t eradicate the voices of familial fat phobia and patriarchal fuckery
I can’t make the hurt stop

But I do promise you this:
I will keep knowing my body is not my worth
I will keep trying to destroy the disgust my wounded soul keeps seeping
And I will keep showing up

Yes
Sweat after sweat
I will keep showing up
for me

And as the endorphins pulse through my veins and the studio lights brighten,

I will find me looking back at me once again

And I will love her – softness, wide curves and all.

Raise your hand if your mental health struggles during the holidays?

#ad Mine sure does. The combination of social pressures, hosting family and the 4pm sunset really affect my well-being and I feel like I need to scale up my care to manage it all.

For me, I am scaling my care by going from once-weekly therapy to twice weekly and I am using allllll the support and wellness tools I’ve got regularly — Waffle, Tugboat, quiet time, art therapy, increased medications, support groups, and community support. 

If you have yet to find a comprehensive treatment management plan that works for you, definitely check out @Charliehealth. I believe this is an excellent option for those looking for that in-between solution. Tackling the youth mental health crisis head-on,  Charlie Health’s Intensive Outpatient Program is built specifically for teens and young adults, ages 12-28, with 9-12 hours weekly of supported groups, family therapy, and one-on-one therapy On top of that, Charlie Health accepts Medicaid and most major insurance programs and has the ability to build a customized payment plan for those without the privilege of insurance, depending on the circumstance. 

Amidst the busy days, it can be hard to remember to take care of yourself and carve out time, especially for your mental health but I want to remind you that:

YOU DESERVE EXACTLY THAT – YOU DESERVE CARE – MENTAL HEALTH CARE.

And today, from the endless battle I fight with my mind, I send love to you and yours.

DISCLAIMER: Insurance and Medicaid plans are assessed on a case-by-case basis. If you have questions about your specific plan, please call 513-847-9458 for more information.

The world lost a beautiful human being this week.
It is heartbreaking. It is not shocking, however.

Death from mental illness is not shocking. 
It is an epidemic. One person dies from mental illness every 11.5 minutes in the US and one person dies from mental illness worldwide every 40 seconds.

Now, what is shocking is that the world continues to act like death from mental illness is surprising when it is the 12th leading cause of death in the United States.

Please do not confuse my frustration at the shock as frustration at the outpouring of love, compassion and support that we have seen in the tragic passing of @sir_twitch_alot. That response is beyond beautiful and it is exactly what we need to address this epidemic. We must harness it for change.

Now, as I sit here — a suicide survivor, a friend who lost 13 people to serious mental illness in her twenties, a human who spent a decade psychotic and suicidal — I am not going to say this work will be easy. It will be heartbreaking and gut-wrenchingly difficult. We will lose so many more spectacular lives. 

And

It is imperative we do this work. 
and It is imperative we begin now.

I’m sure you are nodding right now. I’m sure you are saying - yes, let’s fix this. No more death from mental illness. So, before I jump too far ahead — into the complexity of broken social systems, a health care system in shambles and a world full of stigma it refuses to full acknowledge, I ask you this:

Hold onto this feeling of active compassion.
You will need it for this work will take us decades.

And — before tackling affordable housing, barrier to healthcare access, corrupt insurance companies, overpacked psychiatric units and a world where humans with mental illness are treated more like criminals than the brave warriors they are, let us all begin with these small but oh so meaningful steps this holiday season:
.
Continued 👇

One month of showing up.
For me.
Of sweating — moving — breathing — in a room of other beings in honor of our collective existence.

It’s wild
healing from an eating disorder that pre-dates most of my youth.

It’s been 25 years since it all began.
25 years since my ten year old self bought a tiny notebook with her whole allowance and wrote down every single morsel she consumed after a failed sleepover as she hid beneath the sheets upon returning home.

25 years

of pinching
of measuring
of counting
of starving
of binging
of purging
of running until the very skin on my body began to fall off in blood blisters

Most of all
25 years of unrelenting self hatred

There were many seasons within it
Seasons of aesthetic desire 
Seasons of comfort seeking
Seasons of cruel self punishment

And then,
Then one very long season of wanting
of needing
of living in complete desperation for one tiny semblance of control 
one tiny semblance of control amidst the madness of my mind’s own making.

The really amazing thing is that I’ve been in treatment for all but five of those 25 years.
All but five years and only after trying every version of therapeutic intervention have I finally arrived here
to a place of knowing that the real problem is not the food or the lack there of 
It’s not the movement or its intensity 
They contributed— sure

But the real problem
The real problem that broke me, enslaved me and consumed me entirely
Was the quest for perfection
The quest for something that will not and cannot exist within either myself, my body or the world beyond it.

So today, 
One month in to this new chapter of moving in love and eating in kindness 
I sit here, finally loving that girl I see in the mirror 
as I say,

Perfection be damned.

Yes
Perfection be damned.

The mess is the magic 
and the magic is me.

.
.
.
.

- -

For the full essay head to my link in bio and if you’d like a weekly solidarity story straight to your inbox, please subscribe. I’d love to have you with me for this wild ride of a life out loud with mental illness.

Hey Hey! We’re back in action! While unable to post in feed, I did a whole lot of thinking about this incredible community and how I can create content that offers both joy and meaning. What I kept coming back to is that although my radical transparency is hella different from 99.9% of the content on this app, it is the content that honors all of us the most.

So, before I dive in and double down on this — a little update so that you can prioritize yourself and your health first and foremost.

I am going to start incorporating content that discusses my ongoing recovery from binge eating disorder, body dysmorphic disorder and avoidant anxiety disorder.

Put simply: I will be talking about body neutrality, nutrition, exercise, and exposure therapy on this page.

What does this mean?

1.There will still be dogs - my best girls and so many others. OBVI. 

Dogs are the best & most likely, 95% of my content will be shenanigans with them. 

In addition to that though – there will also be a new focus on how they are the greatest teachers when it comes to finding balance in wellbeing. 

They move freely and with joy. 
They eat with abandon and NEVER feel guilty about extra cookies. 
They love unconditionally - always always always - as they adventure through life finding joy, awe, meaning and glee all the while. 

Talk about wellbeing GOALS.

2. I will be talking about well-being NOT wellness. 
Well-being is not a body size. 
It is not a state of health. 
It is not a diet or fitness plan. 
It is not about shrinking oneself or doing anything that society dictates. 
Simply put, well-being is not an ableist reality of capitalistic f*ckery that is gate kept in its entirety.

3.Wellbeing is a practice.
It is the practice of being present and growing with gratitude.
It is not about arriving anywhere - to a fixed state of body, mind or soul.
It is a daily, evolving practice that is deeply personal and looks, feels and IS different for everyone. 

4.Here, success is showing up.
Here, exactly where we are at right now, is always enough.
And here, everyone’s version of wellbeing is welcome. 
My way is not THE way.
There is no such gosh darn thing.

Continued👇
Yes. Something is wrong with the world.
null

For the past few months, I’ve been asked weekly about when I am going to have my first kid and when I’m going to write my first book. They always throw ‘first’ in there — as if one child or one book would be unsuitable or maybe even inadequate.

I, of course, know that their intention is kind — that their words and word choices are born in flattery. They believe I can do it. They are cheering me on already.

I don’t take offense to these questions any longer. There’s no bite left in the sting that used to burn as tears welled up in my eyes.

But they still get to me a bit.
They still seep in like a good summer rain.

And these days, their words have watered these questions to a point where they keep growing into nagging branches.

When *am* I going to have my first child?
When *am* I going to write my first book?

When I’m tired or overwhelmed and the branches of inquisition hit a little too close, my mind races to ‘When am I going to catch up — to find a way to do it all?’

But after a decent nights sleep or a long walk in the spring sunshine, I can prune away those branches and water the ones that matter most.

What if I can’t honor myself and do it all?
What if I don’t even want to?

Yes,
What if I don’t even want to?

somewhere along the way, we decided human beings needed to justify their fatigue with a societally standardized achievement.

‘I’m tired because…
… I’ve worked an 80 hour week.
… my kids have the flu.
… my baby was up all night.
… I did a really hard workout.
… I went out late with friends.

With this framework, we perpetuated the myth that to be tired is to be weak or broken if it is not the result of capitalistic or societal pursuits.

But that is bullsh*t.
Absolute bullsh*t.

Being human is hard.
Being human is inherently exhausting, especially in this digital world.
And being tired as a result of our humanity is normal — entirely normal — and a testament to our survival.

So if this weekend, you’re tired, I say this:

Me too.
Bigtime me too.
And that doesn’t make you broken or weak.
That makes you a human.
A human who is inherently worthy of rest, no matter what.

So from me and my own Snoozletown Sunday, I send love and pride from a gal who will say when asked what she did this weekend,

I rested. And it was the most productive weekend I could have possibly had.

Stay gentle + of course dorky,
Kspeer
what if? indeed. ✨
it’s also how *you* light up the world too ✨ never forget that. It’s how you light up the world too 💜😘

always. always. always. I have me.
just as you have you.

I no longer work at The Dogist. I could say many things about my incredible time there — the dogs, the adventures, the people, the places, and oh — the good we have done together.

I could also share the details — as I usually do — about Elias’ decision to restructure the business and let go of me, Isabel and Jacquie in the process. But this moment isn’t about that.

This moment is about you.

Five and a half years ago, scared shitless, I got on a stage with Waffle and I told a story. I told my story. And for those twenty odd minutes in front of an assorted crowd in a packed room, I was at home. I was in actual alignment with my purpose — with who I am and who I was always meant to be — a storyteller.

The places that one spoken story has taken me are nothing short of remarkable. They honestly still feel surreal, especially as I take a closer look at the past five years.

When I got the job at The Dogist and every day thereafter, people would say “Oh my God! You are the luckiest! Dogs?! You work with dogs?!”

They weren’t wrong. I absolutely was the luckiest. And I still am the luckiest.

But to my surprise and likely yours as well, the reason I’m the luckiest is not because of the dogs.

The reason I’m the luckiest is you.

You loved us.
You showed up for us.
You invited us in and shared your stories.
 
And with each story, we spun a web together, a safety net of truth that humans — especially humans in the presence of dogs — can be good, deeply truly good.

So today, as I ponder on what is next for me and I begin dreaming up the next adventure — I leave you with this.

Thank you.

Thank you from the bottom, the top, the everywhere in my heart.

You helped heal me in a way I never thought possible and I will forever be grateful for the beauty and good that is you.

May you never lose it and may you always know that your goodness — it is the light of this world and it will forever guide all of us home.

With love,
k

~

If you would like to support our work as we navigate this unexpected transition, please consider becoming a subscriber to our substack. The link is in stories + at the link in bio on @kate_speer

Given my unabashed and goofy nature, it’s hard for people to believe that I was agoraphobic for years. The time I spent living in near isolation, terrified of the world with only my imaginary best friend Maura by my side was definitely the darkest chapter of my life. 

Starting nine years ago, I did extensive exposure therapy to work through it and when I got Waffle, I kicked my exposures into hyper drive. Together, we tackled my fear. Together, we tackled the world. And together, we found freedom — a freedom I’d never even dreamt of — one of travel, cities, speaking gigs, friends all over the world and so so much opportunity.

When Covid arrived here in the US and quarantine began, agoraphobic behaviors were not just mandatory, they were considered life saving. And so, of course, I followed them to a T. As time passed, my body began to confuse the decision to stay home for the safety of others and myself for the dark years I spent agoraphobic and consumed by fear. After a year or so of isolation, my body entirely forgot how to walk out the door without having a panic attack. In a matter of months, I went from living with the joy of anxiety-free freedom that Waffle and I had worked so hard to find to a state of near complete relapse.

It became quite clear that I needed to start exposure therapy again and just as I began it in early 2022, Waffle almost died when her spleen ruptured. Shortly thereafter, Waffle lost her ability to walk.

This week, in my newsletter, I talk about the grief that has accompanied me this past year. I write about learning to leave the house again and how this new chapter of life after The Dogist is yet another chance to learn to walk out the door and begin once more.

The full piece is at the link in my bio.

As always, thank you so much for being here with me. You — my beloved community — are such a gift.

Wishing you a day.

Kindly,
Kspeer

I’ll be the first to celebrate and elevate good causes and great stories. But somehow, I struggle deeply with doing that for myself. 

Exhibit one ☝️— my essay on grief, learning to care for myself and facing my fears by once again, walking out my door — that I never shared here.

It’s definitely wild how hard it is for me to ask you all to read my work in a different setting. It’s as if I don’t yet fully believe that my words are worthy of your inbox or attention. 

That said, as I slowly begin to learn what living for myself looks like — what life after The Dogist looks like — and what really trying to become a writer entails, I must learn to do it.

So, here’s take one at shameless self promotion — 

Please join me in my writing adventures by subscribing to my weekly newsletter — Probably Anxious — at the link in my bio.

My newsletter is about this next chapter and all that came before it. Each Friday, I send out an essay — about now or then and everything in between. 

If you’d like to help support me in this, there is a paid option too but please feel absolutely no pressure to do so. Any way you show up there is a gift. Paid subscribers get access to exclusive content and my monthly column — THE PATIENT IS IN — a solidarity/advice column where I answer questions about life with serious mental illness.

I really hope to see you there!

With love and so much gratitude for YOU 💜😘

Kindly,
Kate

Not a day goes by where someone doesn’t preface their curiosity with an apology. I know it’s their way of being polite and I totally get it as I often do the same. 

But when I really think about it, it’s odd that we are wired this way — wired to apologize for doing the very thing that honors someone’s truth.

Kind curiosity is the opposite of shame.

Kind curiosity — people asking about the very being that I am, its dark corners, soft sorrow and all — heals.

So please, at least with me, ask away. Care enough to get curious. Dare enough to be invited all the way in.
Subscribe to my free Friday newsletter at the link in bio. My newest piece goes live today at noon Eastern Standard Time.
Living — the both — forever and always.

Subscribe to my Substack at the link in bio to join me as I grow onto this next chapter.
~
Explanation of video below 👇 
~
There is no wrong way to be human. Teaching this and normalizing the breadth of the human condition — most notably, pain and it’s many manifestations — will be the work of my lifetime.

In the dark, it’s hard — often nearly impossible — to remember that our minds and emotions are not always based in fact. My life of late has been an adventure exploring that truth, walking that line and reminding myself over and over and over again, my feelings and thoughts are not facts.

Feeling and thoughts are valid — always always always valid. But here they are reflections of my life past. They are demons of the dark, imposters from my twenties dropping in and screaming lie after lie that I’m still broken, that I’m still not worthy of existence and that just like that doctor once said, I’d be better off dead.

The second part of this video shows me in the depth of a PTSD flashback reliving those past thoughts and feelings. I’m fighting for the present moment — trying for it with every therapeutic practice I’ve learned throughout the video.

But the pain does not diminish in face of simply a fight or recitation of facts. It diminishes only when we remember that it is merely a part of us.

And when we do, its power diminishes. When we do, when we let it belong within us as a mere mountain in a landscape or somber dress hanging in the depth of our closet, its beastly hold lessens and we rise — whole, worthy and capable of feeling the light alongside the pain once again.

I share this because this lived experience is part of me. I don’t share this for pity or attention. I share this to normalize being a whole human. Like I said at the beginning, there is no wrong way to be human and the sooner we uphold this truth — live it, breathe it, celebrate it — the sooner millions of lives will be saved from the suicide epidemic and the sooner you and I will be at home in our whole selves.

~

To learn more about this, subscribe to my free newsletter at the link in my bio. Hope to see you there.

When I crashed my car into a pole this spring while driving solo, I thought my life as I knew it was over. It was the first time I experienced a fugue-induced car accident and the very idea that this body and being of mine could hurt someone when I got behind the wheel each day absolutely terrified me.

I have had innumerable fugue states since I started having them in my twenties after I was sexually assaulted, but I have never gotten in a car accident during one. I have also never hurt anyone else in a fugue state, only myself. But this spring, as my neck snapped to and the shock of my car slamming to a halt reverberated through my whole spine, I reckoned in panic with my condition’s potential to harm others.
After the accident,  as I drove fifteen miles an hour blasting sing-alongs with the windows wide open to the frigid night air to keep me alert and attentive, I replayed the night over and over again. 

What had happened?
Where did I go?
What if I had hurt someone? 

Of course, I didn’t remember anything. That is how fugue states work. The mind severs the connection with the body in pursuit of self protection and memories of that time period completely disappear. Sometimes, memories return in the form of night terrors, but oftentimes they are gone for good.

That night, just like my memory of the evening, I thought my freedom was gone for good too. As soon as I made it sluggishly yet safely home, my immediate reaction was to email my care team and announce my decision to never drive again. I went to bed thinking that was it – that I would never know the freedom I once had – that I would forever be dependent on someone else to go anywhere ever again.

Continued at the link in my bio 👆

And as always, thank you so much for being here and reading my words.

I AM OFFICIALLY READY FOR THIS NEXT CHAPTER! WHO’S EXCITED?!

I am going to kick off my adventure into full time mental illness advocacy with a focus on (the hell that is) anxiety.

I’ll be talking about — what it is, how it manifests and how it is actually our body attempting to love and protect us. Yup, I know that sounds insane but it is actually the case. 

First, I’m going to break down what anxiety is and how it shows up in the body and mind.

Then, I’m going to explain what exposure therapy is, how it works and how we can do it safely.

Thereafter, I’ll be sharing personal stories about the many manifestations of my own anxiety — stories about all sorts of things — learning differences, different forms of eating disorders, GI challenges, OCD and agoraphobia — and actively show up as I work through them using exposure therapy.

My goal in this is to normalize discomfort — to empower the understanding that discomfort is growth — and to celebrate each individual’s innate power to heal themselves.

Now, if this sounds like bullshit — like rainbows and unicorns and fairy dust — I challenge you to stick around because I was you. I believed I was doomed to the hell that is crippling life-disabling anxiety. AND I NO LONGER HAVE LIFE-DISABLING ANXIETY.

IT IS THE BEST GD THING EVER & you deserve it!

I am so excited to share this with you because even if you don’t yet believe in yourself, I do. 

I believe in you & I know you can set yourself free of the hell of anxiety.

I honestly can’t wait to show you the innate power that has been within your being all along.

Drop a 🥳 below if you’re excited (and by that I mean absolutely terrified 🫠😅)!

Kindly + with a dork dance,
Kate

DISCLAIMER: I am not a therapist. I will be working with my care team to make sure all shared is done with the most up to date science.

That said, what I share here is not a replacement for medical treatment.

It is also not suited for individuals who are actively experiencing suicidal ideation or suicidality of any kind. 

If this is you right now, there is no shame in that place. The world is not kind to people like us but please dial 988. I want you here. Actually, I need you here.

Before we dive into all things anxiety, please hear this loud and clear — actually, please *feel* this loud and clear:

ALL OF YOU BELONGS HERE.

EVERYTHING YOU FEEL IS VALID AND REAL.

And at least with me, 

EVERYTHING YOU FEEL IS SAFE TO BE FELT AND LOVINGLY ACCEPTED without any presumption that I get it.

These are the three great truths of this community we are going to build together and I ask that you hold onto these truths as we move into this work together. 

I ask this of you because when I talk through the science of anxiety and the work of exposure therapy, it can often present as if I am trying to diminish your pain or talk you out of your truth like every other misinformed a**hole who suggests you “just not think about it.” 

Honestly, that’s how it felt the first time my doctor explained it. It felt like he was trying to tell me that what I felt wasn’t valid because there was a solution.

That reaction is wholly valid AND it is also never my intention. My intention is to never invalidate any truth of yours. Ever.

My intention is to grow you through that truth — to hold space for the duality that it can be miserable AND healed — and to harness the discomfort of that misery to make the many tomorrows of your life better.

So — one more time for the people in the back —

ALL OF YOU BELONGS HERE, EXACTLY AS YOU ARE.

And whether you feel it or not, or believe it or not,

I love you.
I believe in you.
And I am so excited to be here with you on this adventure.

With love + a dork dance.

Kindly,
Kate

~
~
~
PS I’ve been thinking about what to call all of this…. Fear camp… Anxieties Anonymous… if you have any ideas, drop them below 💜👇😘

WHAT ACTUALLY IS ANXIETY?? Before you read, comment your answer 👇👇👇

Most people believe anxiety is an emotion and, while most use it that way, that’s actually not the case.

Anxiety is a reaction – a reaction to stress, to something we perceive is a threat.

ANXIETY = [A THREAT] + [THE BELIEF WE CANNOT HANDLE THAT THREAT]

Anxiety manifests in both the mind and in the body.

Evolutionarily, anxiety served to save our life – it was our way of protecting ourselves from deadly threats. 

Imagine living hundreds of years ago and running into a grizzly bear. Anxiety in the form of the Fight/Flight/Freeze response appeared and was a perfect survival reaction. Our body filled with cortisol and adrenaline so we could fight the grizzly, run away from the grizzly, or play dead in front of the grizzly. Back then, anxiety served our survival. It was our body’s way of protecting us.

Fast forward to now – where a work deadline, social gathering, or dessert may trigger anxiety. In these instances, our minds and bodies react as if the work deadline/social gathering/dessert is as deadly as a grizzly bear. As our minds and bodies perceive these threats as something we cannot handle, like a grizzly bear, our bodies go into fight/flight/freeze as our bodies try to protect us. 

BUT in today’s world, this reaction does not serve us.

Now, you are probably sitting there nodding your head and saying - but how the HELL do I make all these awful uncomfortable reactions go away?

This week, I am going to teach you but today’s lesson is learning this:

Anxiety is a reaction to stress that evolved to save us.

Anxiety is our body and mind trying to protect us – to love us and save us in face of deadly threats. 

And the work – all that we will do to heal our anxiety – is not about hating our bodies or minds and their reactions. 

It is about working with them and teaching them that all the threats we perceive as deadly threats are actually things that we can handle living through.

The work is literally teaching our bodies that all these things that trigger anxiety are not deadly grizzly bears. 

More on how to befriend our grizzly bears soon.

💜
K, W + T

I have felt completely stuck these past few months — waking each morning to write my memoir but the only words that come out are ruminations about what happened at the dogist.
The only subject where my fingers fly on the keyboard is a subject I’ve tricked myself into believing is not one I can share.

I’ve analyzed it from every side and every corner.
I’ve excavated both myself and the seven tupperwares of paperwork I saved thinking one day I’d be writing that book.

But each day, as I write it out, I grow smaller.
Each day, as I stay silent, I perpetuate the fallacy that it’s not okay to be all that I am — that I don’t even get to own all that I am.
And that is not the case.

There is a difference between honesty and disparagement and I refuse to let fear paralyze me any longer.

So, today I reclaim the truth that will be my life’s work — 

There is no wrong way to be human, as long as one is honest and kind.

So today, I do exactly that.

I share a solo podcast episode about my experiences at the dogist for paid subscribers. It’s quite brief — a mere twenty minutes — but it shares my story and the part I played in it.

If you care to listen, head to the link in my bio and whether you do or not, I ask that you keep your thoughts on what happened at The Dogist to yourself. 

This is the end of that book for me and in order to truly leave it behind, I need it to rest peacefully on the shelf for a long while.

With snugs from the girls.

Kindly,
Kate

I don’t know exactly what happened
How I ended up with fancy black dresses and a beige house
How I became obsessed with what’s “right”and respected
And how I transformed into someone determined to be liked over all else 

But I did

I landed here
In no man’s land

Somewhere between fighting my mind’s demons and trying to prove to the world that I could live beyond the bounds of a ward 
I lost the one thing I could always count on

I lost me.

Professionalism over personality
Eloquence over honesty 
Beauty over boldness
Trend over truth

And most of all

Yes
Most of all

Being liked by others over loving myself

It didn’t happen all at once 
And it certainly didn’t happen in a day or even a year

But I stopped dancing
I stopped wearing electric salmon everything
I stopped running up mountains with a picnic dinner at dusk and biking from cremee stand to cremee stand all over vermont

And most of all
Yes most of all
I stopped saying exactly how I feel as I let the terror of being wrong, messy and unlovable take hold

I keep wishing people would talk about it
How aggressively we cling to identities and diagnoses
How people pleasing is the very currency we traffic our existence in
How devoted we are to societal norms built from the ruins of oppression and abuse 

And most of all 
How terrifying it is to simply say
I don’t know
Maybe anything
But definitely who I am

Yes I keep wishing 
People would talk about it
That people would admit it 
Loud
And clear 
And true

So today
I am

Today
I say

I don’t know who I am

All I know is 
Somewhere along the way
I lost her
And even though I’m terrified to not be liked, I’m more terrified to live a life without the true me beating in my chest.

I’m writing a book, and I need your help:

Please subscribe to my Substack at the link in my bio. It is free to join and every subscriber counts and honestly, matters deeply to me.

Thank you for being here with me on this wild ride.

With love and a dork dance,
Kspeer

I’ve been advocating for mental health since I was fifteen. It’s taken me 20 years to finally understand this and I want to emphasize it loud and clear:

You’re not too much.

You’ve simply been with the wrong people. 

#seriousmentalillness #mentalhealthawareness

Welcome to my next chapter. Rather, welcome to my purpose — the thing I’ve done since I was in second grade and the new kid was bullied — a career in mental health advocacy and activism.

It’s wild it took me this long for my mind to distill all that I’ve lived through into one chronological timeline. But that’s the truth and so here I am — finally aware of this freedom I have AND the depths of trauma that I experienced.

Being able to feel both I am flabbergasted at the opportunity that lies in front of me.

So, consider this a little PSA that things are about to get even more unabashed/dorky/grateful/loud/colorful/spicy on this channel.

There is a raging su1c1de epidemic going on and it’s time to take it on with all the stories.

Thank you for the honor of being here with me.

It is a gift — a pure gift.

I love you.
Kspeer
Five years. Holy wow. We are the luckiest @lutzda 💜✨😘

I have struggled with binge eating disorder for 30 years. I binged for the first time when I was 6.

Food is love and comfort. It is also warfare.

Food is how I process my emotions — how I soothe them, hear them, control them and punish them.

I want to heal my relationship with food which really means I want to heal my relationship with anxiety.

This means I’m going to be sharing a lot of behavioral therapy on this page — exposure therapy, in particular.

A few important things to note:

I am not a therapist and what I share is not therapy.

Everything I share will incorporate the most up to date science (to the best of my ability) and I will mess up and own it when I do. 

Fat is not a bad word.

I will be discussing food, body image, societal pressure, racial discrimination, thin privilege, capitalism, body positivity and politics and how they interact with the eating disorder and body acceptance community. 

I will not be able to unpack all of these very important realities in every post so please be patient with me. Food and body image are complicated AF and breaking down how everything is connected is subject for a dissertation not an Instagram post. So again, if you can, please practice patience.

I am thin privileged.

I also live with body dysmorphic disorder.

These two realities are not mutually exclusive — ie just because I am thin privileged does not mean I love my body. Please hold onto this coexistence.

I will be discussing exercise and nutrition on this page.

I am going to mess up. I am human.

This content IS NOT for anyone actively living with anorexia, bulimia or orthorexia. If this is you, I love you. I was you and PLEASE UNFOLLOW ME until you discuss it with your doctor.

I’m terrified.

I’m doing it anyway.

37 year old Kate deserves this.

There is no such thing as a bad feeling.

Emotions are teachers.

Binge Eating Disorder is a coping technique.

It is a maladaptive coping technique but it is still me coping and it is critical to honor that. 

To work through my binge eating, I must first recognize this is not about the food.

It is about the feelings behind the food.

This is about my pain and anxiety.

I need to make that pain safe.

I need to make that anxiety safe.

This does not mean I need to love this pain or anxiety. It merely means I need to accept it as part of me instead of thinking I need to control it, soothe it or punish it with food.

So let me give you a brief overview of how I plan to heal out loud in front of you.

First, I am going to talk through anxiety. 

This will involve a discussion about what anxiety is, how it manifests in my body, how it manifests in the mind and how these manifestations of mind and body perpetuate anxious feelings.

Then, I will share my process of building out an exposure therapy plan starting with physical sensation exposures and then moving into active exposures. I will share these by sharing my actual exposures with you. 

Thereafter, once I have laid a foundation of what anxiety is and what exposure therapy looks like, I will then begin to unpack the intersection of body image and binge eating disorder. This is a very complicated dynamic but it is foundational to the work I will be doing.

Lastly, I will begin unpacking the many complexities that body image, society, capitalism, race, discrimination and politics bring into play. Note, I only said begin because I am not yet ready to get a phD and this whole thing is insanely complex.

So yup. Long story long.

There is no such thing as a bad feeling.

Feelings simply are and all of yours are safe with me.

Ii love you.

Kindly,
Kate

As a reminder: I am not a therapist. This is not medical advice. This is my solidarity story. If you are in crisis now,  please text HOME to 741741. We need you here with us.

As I sit with the uncertainty of this undiagnosed breast lump, I’ve reconnected with the time I spent waiting to hear from my best friend Maura after she was placed on psychiatric hold.

I loved writing this piece for you this week. It was deeply healing and there was something magical about feeling my words as they spilled out onto the page. It’s almost as if I was feeling the experience for the first time. Then again, since I was so heavily medicated back then — maybe I really was feeling them fully for the first time. 

Either way, writing about Maura is always a gift and I am so excited to share more of her with you today in the piece at the link in my bio.

Whenever I write about Maura, I am always reminded to love my people loudly. Maura had a way of showing up so fully in the moment that I couldn’t help but feel fully seen and celebrated by her. Truthfully, there was an armor to her love. It protected me from my own darkness and the rest of the world’s darkness too. With Maura, it didn’t matter if she made a scene, if her hug was awkwardly long, or if her laugh disrupted the whole room. It didn’t matter how many people stared at us and our shenanigans when I was with her because her love overpowered the rest of the world and it’s judgements.

I’ve been trying to reconnect with this way of loving — with long smooshy hugs and gleeful yelps when a friend pulls in the driveway. It often feels scary to do it — vulnerable, naked even. But I never regret it afterward. In actuality, I think I’m grateful for it afterward because it’s brought me so much closer to many friends.

I’m rambling now but I guess what I’m saying is — let’s both give it a try this weekend. Let’s love loudly. Let’s show up for our people. It just might bring us our next best friend and heal a hard time someone is fighting through.

Head to my link in bio for my piece about the healing power of loud love in times of deep, dark uncertainty.

Wishing you a weekend.

Kindly + with loud love,
Kate

FEAR CAMP — LESSON 1 

THIS IS THE MOST IMPORTANT LESSON:

EVERYTHING YOU FEEL IS ALWAYS VALID.

ALWAYS.

I need you to know this in your heart of hearts before joining me on this fear camp adventure.

The reason being — discussions of anxiety, binge eating and behavioral therapy involve discussions of science. And science often feels deeply invalidating.

I absolutely get this. I lived this. Truly.

Every time a doctor explained this stuff it felt like they were saying “suck it up buttercup” / “get over yourself.”

That is NOT what I’m doing here.

AND

Some of my solidarity lessons might bring up those feelings and that is very normal.

So — please — here me loud and clear:

EVERYTHING YOU FEEL IS VALID.

Your pain — your suffering — it is very real and I am so sorry you are living through it.

I am so sorry.

My hope is to solidarity teach you that your pain is real AND your ability to heal through that pain is also real.

This adventure will not be for everyone. 

It is going to be uncomfortable— a lot of the time.

THAT IS THE GROWTH. THAT IS THE HEALING.

and you don’t have to stay with me through this discomfort.

whether you do or not,

I don’t presume to get your fight.

At all.

AND

I’m here with you.

I love you.

and I wholeheartedly believe in us both.

Wishing you a day,

Kindly, 
Kate

WHAT HAPPENS TO YOUR BODY WHEN YOU ARE ANXIOUS? Write a list of the physical sensations in the comments below 👇

Now, for todays lesson!

WHAT ACTUALLY IS ANXIETY??

Anxiety is a reaction – a reaction to stress, to something we perceive is a threat.

ANXIETY = A THREAT + THE BELIEF WE CANNOT HANDLE THAT THREAT

Anxiety can be broken down into two parts:

1.The physical response to that perceived threat

2.The thoughts we have in response to that physical response

Evolutionarily, anxiety served to save our life – it was our way of protecting ourselves from deadly threats. 

This is very important to remember because it means anxiety is literally our body’s way of CARING for ourselves so we survive.

Imagine living hundreds of years ago and running into a grizzly bear. 

Anxiety in the form of the Fight/Flight/Freeze response appeared and was a perfect survival reaction. 

Our body filled with cortisol and adrenaline so we could fight the grizzly, run away from the grizzly, or play dead in front of the grizzly. 

Back then, anxiety served our survival. It was our body’s way of protecting us.

Fast forward to now – where a work deadline, social gathering, or dessert may trigger anxiety. 

In these instances, our bodies react as if the work deadline/social gathering/dessert is as deadly as a grizzly bear.

BUT in today’s world, this reaction does not serve us.

Now, you are probably sitting there nodding your head and saying - but how the HELL do I make all these awful uncomfortable reactions go away?

Well that’s where exposure therapy comes in.

In order to do exposure therapy, we must be able to identify our own physical sensations in times of anxiety.

And that’s todays homework — identifying the physical sensations of anxiety in our bodies.

What happens in your body? 

Write a list in the comments below or in a notebook.

And know that no matter what, I LOVE YOU!

Xo
Kspeer

LESSON # 3 — ANXIETY + THE MIND. What thoughts come up when you experience anxiety? Share them in the comments below 👇

As we established yesterday,

Anxiety is a reaction to a perceived threat.

Anxiety can be broken down into two parts:

1.The physical response to that perceived threat

2.The thoughts we have in response to that physical response

Today, we are learning to identify the thoughts we have in response to the perceived threat.

Now, before I break it all down, let me say clearly that recognizing what is happening in our mind when feeling anxious takes a lot of time and practice. 

So, if this feels very abstract, that is totally normal. It took me years to get this fully.

AND

this concept being abstract doesn’t mean we can’t handle it so let’s dive in…

When our body reacts to a perceived threat, we feel all the physical sensations we identified yesterday — sweat, blurred vision, heart racing, IBS, etc.

As soon as we feel these uncomfortable sensations, we immediately think a whole slew of negative thoughts.

For me, as soon as the anxious physical sensations are pulsing through my body, my mind starts screaming YOU CAN’T HANDLE THIS, KATE! GET OUT KATE, GET OUT OF HERE!

For a very long time, those thoughts were subconscious. I could not identify them and I certainly could not tolerate them. Now I can and this skill transforms my life daily.

So, just as with the physical sensations, identification is critical in being able to learn to tolerate them.

So, today, let’s break down a list of all the cruel things our mind spews at us in times of anxiety in the comments below

 👇 👇👇

Our mind can be quite the bully so please know what you share here is a thought and not a fact.

And though I know it’s not fun — I promise, it will be worth it when we finally learn to tame our grizzle bears into cuddly waffles together.

I love you.
Kate

LESSON # 4 — The warrior hood of living with anxiety. How much time do spend daily fighting your anxiety?

Anxiety can be an all-consuming beast.

More often then not, we punish ourselves for our anxiety instead of giving ourselves credit for the incredible amount of work that goes into managing it.

But it is SO MUCH WORK

AND

That hard work deserves so much credit!

Before diving into exposure therapy next week, we must CELEBRATE THAT WORK and acknowledge that every single day we are living through both the physical sensations and the cruel thoughts that our mind conjures.

We also must identify how much time we are spending each day navigating our anxiety.

How much time do you spend navigating your anxiety? Ten minutes? An hour? Five hours? All day? All night?

SHARE HOW MUCH TIME YOU SPEND FIGHTING ANXIETY EVERY DAY IN THE COMMENTS BELOW.

This figure will help anchor us as we begin our exposure therapy adventure. 

This figure will also serve as a reminder for how capable and strong YOU ALREADY ARE.

Yes, YOU ARE ALREADY KICKING ASS. It is just about using the skill that is exposure therapy to help that work pay off.

That’s it for fear camp this week. I’m off to sleep all weekend but before I do I want to remind you of this —

I don’t presume to get your fight.

And I am here with you.

I am here with you and I wholeheartedly believe in us both.

I love you.

Kindly,
Kate

Before we dive into exposure therapy tomorrow, 4 important things to note:

1.RECOVERY IS POSSIBLE FOR EVERYONE.

Recovery is the coexistence of a meaningful and joyful life WITH the daily management of symptoms. 

Recovery looks different for everyone.

Everyone is worthy of recovery.

AND

If you are in an active state of crisis, fear camp is not for you to do in a self directed manner.

If you are actively living with suicidal ideation, self harm and suicide planning, fear camp is not suited for you and your well-being.

YOU ARE ABSOLUTELY WORTHY of recovery and this framework.

AND

In order to do exposure therapy safely, it is paramount that you do this with the help of a professional not here with me.

Please know I say this to protect you because I love you.

I also say this because I was you. 

I promise I will not stop fighting until there is an accessible framework for you to do this.

That is unfortunately, however, not today.

So, if you are in crisis, please choose you and unfollow me or at the very least mute me/do not engage with this content.

2. I am a human who lived this.

I am a public health educator with a team of scientists and trauma specialists behind the scenes scientifically accrediting what I share here.

I am not a therapist, a crisis counselor or a doctor. 

THIS IS NOT TREATMENT. 

THIS IS HABIT STACKING BACKED BY NEUROSCIENCE.

3.This work is hard and in order to do it effectively, you must get uncomfortable. 

More than that, you must lean into that discomfort.

Remember lesson # 4 though — you are already doing that work bravely every day as you fight anxiety.

4. You matter and you are already enough, exactly as you are.

Whether you do this or not, 

YOU MATTER. 

YOU DESERVE RECOVERY. 

YOU BELONG HERE WITH ME.

YOU BELONG HERE WITH US.

and no matter what,

I see you.

I don’t presume to get your fight.

AND

I wholeheartedly believe in us both.

I love you.

Kspeer

Yesterday, I spoke on a panel at @projecthealthyminds World Mental Health Day Festival. It’s hard to believe that this is real life.

We use phrases like this — ‘I can’t believe it’ —‘how is this real life?’ — all the time.
I love the connotation and optimism these phrases often hold. 
But for me, when I say I don’t believe it — it’s a bit more complicated.

I spent a decade psychotic and over the course of those ten years, my life was a mosaic of mirages. 
Many people, places and things that I saw with my own two eyes and trusted as foundational parts of my life were not real. 
They did not exist at all because they were hallucinations.

Building a life on the back of the imaginary proved to be my yellow brick road out of madness and off disability.
It was a terrifying, wild & deeply lonely road until Waffle joined me.

Even then — even after Waffle taught me what was real and what wasn’t, I still felt profound shame and distrust within myself.

The accumulation of a decade of hallucinations and the questions I’d asked myself over and over again didn’t simply disappear and I found myself still asking them.

If I’m being perfectly honest, I still ask these questions, especially on days like yesterday —

Am I actually here with @thepsychdoctormd and @justme.rod or is this one massive psychotic break I am living from the inside of a psych ward?

Is @carsondaly actually waving at us before he goes to speak with Prince Harry, Megan and @drvivekmurthy or is he simply an imaginary version that my mind conjured from my hospital bed?

Every time I ask one of these questions, I plant a seed of doubt.
Over the years, these many seeds have grown into a thorny hillside that l am perpetually tangled within.

But yesterday, I ~did~ speak at the world mental health festival in New York City.
.
Continued 👇

Pinch me. Waffy and I are in the @nytimes ➡️ today. What an honor.

This means I can finally tell you what I’m doing with Harvard — building out public mental health campaigns to grow a healthier, safer and more accessible future! 

Mental Health for all — Let’s goooooo!🔥🔥🔥

Massive thank you to Ellen Barry and @sarahblesener for the incredible piece and photographs.

Huge thank you to @harvardchansph for recognizing the power of online advocacy and giving me the chance to help shape the future with it.

And most of all,

THE BIGGEST OF BIG THANK YOUS TO YOU! 

I am here because of you!

I have been creating mental health content for 9.5 years (10 years this December) and this community is a pure gift to me. A pure gift. 

I am so proud of how far we’ve come and oooh baby, I cannot wait to see where we go and all the good we will do along the way.

We love you.

Kate, Dave, Waffy + Tug

This bill would prohibit the sale of weight loss supplements to minors.

Not only are these products gateways to eating disorders, the deadliest mental illness, these products are also often laced with additives that result in long term physical harm.

The first time I was called fat I was in first grade.

I was as tall as my older sister
My legs were thicker too
and the kids on our tiny school bus thought it was funny to point out

I’ve been ashamed of my body ever since.

This body of mine and me
We’ve been through many seasons of struggle together.

Some lasted longer than the others.

Calorie counting lasted 21 years.

Bulimia lasted 12.

Orthorexia lasted 2.

Anorexia lasted only 1.

But binge eating — 
binge eating is the season I still live within.
It’s the season I’ve been living in since I was 5 years old.

Six years ago, 
I finally made progress in accepting this body of mine — 
in moving beyond the ever gnawing need to shrink it.

I wrote about it here
In front of you.

I was terrified
And I did it anyways. 

And then,
just like the bullies on that tiny school bus, 
bullies found me here.

Yes
Just when I finally jiggled for joy and meant it
When I finally accepted this body as what it is
a vessel that does not signify worth — not even one tiny bit

People from the very community I was advocating for bullied me into silence once again.

You’re too thin to be body positive, some said.

You’re too fat to be an eating disorder advocate, others said.

And my mind
the greatest bully of all
heard them and joined in, 
Screaming hate into every corner of my being
Screaming hate until I retreated fully into silence.

I relapsed fully and completely after that.

Binging became the only avenue to get through the day.

Pile of candy bars after pile of candy bars
Stack of pizzas after stack of pizzas

I’m not mad at myself for binging
Binging is how I cope with pain.
And I’m not mad at myself for hurting.

But I am mad at myself for going silent 
For listening to the bullies.
For believing them.

So today, from me and ➡️these pants that will never fit,
I take my first step back towards that jiggling for joy human.

Yes,
today,
I take a step back towards recovery and say —

This is me.
I’m not skinny.
I’m not fat.
And — 
even if I don’t look the part you want me to play,
This is my truth.

I live with debilitating binge eating disorder and I belong here even if that makes you uncomfortable.

When is enough — enough?

Thinking of everyone in Maine this morning and sending so much love your way — even though I know, love is not enough when it comes to this.

Also — if this makes you uncomfortable or feels “off brand” for me — this is a mental health issue because this is a human safety issue.

There is no mental health without safety.

After my ADHD diagnosis at age 16, unbeknownst to me, a long, elaborate path of dominoes began to fall. At first, they fell slowly, as if the dominoes were stacked up a steep hill — a stimulant prescription, a depression diagnosis, bouts of sleeplessness, and rage that presented like hypomania. Then — after a tumultuous first semester at college, upon my receiving the diagnosis of bipolar disorder, the dominos fell at a speed that left no option but complete wreckage as the end result — polypharmacy, electroconvulsive therapy, long-term memory loss, paranoia, OCD, psychosis, sexual assault, fugue states, agoraphobia, and chronic psychiatric hospitalizations. 

It’s simple when I look back at the path of dominoes now – when I see the chain of events that brought me to Maura. But one factor that grounded me, honored me, & supported me throughout the chaos of those many years was Atlas, my long-time therapist. He had championed me since that first diagnosis of ADHD at 16. He had been my therapist for 8 years – all the way through Middlebury College. Being before the normalization of Telehealth appointments, I had actually driven the hour and a half drive to his office every single week. In rain, hail, sleet, and snow – I had gone to see him every single Tuesday. In many ways, he was more influential than anyone in my life. I trusted him implicitly and as I sat there on that couch, a wave of relief rippled through me as I saw him finally take pride in my being for the first time in years as I shared the progress of big little victories with him.

As the relief washed over both of us, I couldn’t help but name it. Cracking a joke about how it was about time I got my shit together, I was met with an unusual response — frustration. Thereafter, came a flood of his own personal news.  It was as if my good news had conjured a door to the world beyond our therapeutic relationship and my humor had opened it for him to walk through.

What started as an expression of his exhaustion at my “relentless symptoms and self-pity” quickly divulged into an angry onslaught of updates about his rapidly declining personal health.

Continued at the link👆

1/3 It all started sixteen years ago in the psych ward. Psychotic, hypomanic, and raging against a world that never seemed to love me back, I began to scribble in one of my college notebooks:.

______

What if the world could tell me who was safe and who wasn’t?

What if — amidst my mind on fire and imaginary demons — there was a symbol for who I can trust with my truth?

What if — when my mind wants me to die but I don’t actually want to — there is a way to know which door to knock on?
~

I need a goddamn Underground Railroad for people like me.

I need a beacon, a code, a flickering candle in the window that proclaims safety.

I need something.

We need something.

~

There’s the pride flag.

There’s the pink ribbons for breast cancer.

But where the heck is the symbol for — I love you in all of your colors and seasons and even if what you say is terrifying and heartbreaking, all of you is safe with me, exactly as you are? 

Yeah where the hell is that?

What is solidarity, safety and support? In a symbol? 

And what if you could wear it on your sleeve?

____

Follow @mentalhealthiscool__ to join me on this new adventure.

I can’t wait to see you there.

💜💜💜

2/3 Over the course of the next two weeks in the ward, I drew t-shirts and sweatshirts and buttons and pins. Then I moved on to collage — to the idea that the apparel could involve a community art project component — not everyone would want ‘batshit crazy’ on a Tshirt, after all, but everyone loves art. 

What if there was a mountain collection for mountain lovers by someone who lives in the mountains with mental illness that supports mental illness? 

And what if there’s an abstract art collection by a colorful artist that actually contains and celebrates all the colors that all of us are? Yes – that’s it. What if every single piece was by someone with mental illness for someone with mental illness? And what if the profits funded their work and making mental health accessible? Cool even? What if we could make mental health cool?

My room in the psych ward became my art studio. Collage cutouts, doodles galore and scribble-covered paper covered every inch of the room. My doctors upped my meds at that point assuming it was a manic break. And the truth was — maybe it was a manic break. But the antipsychotics didn’t stop me. I kept scribbling. I kept sketching. I kept cutting pieces of paper into abstract art. And most of all, I kept believing in a world that would love me and people like me back. I kept believing in a future that held actual safety for people in the darkest of darkness.

I first came across my sketches six years ago. The art project framework — the idea that each collection elevated a different artist and there was a symbol to connect community — was what we used at The Dogist to launch The Dogist Sshop. But dog lovers are accepted — beloved actually — so the project, although successful, did not hold the power I’d always dreamt of.

At some point in the last five years, I got scared to be me.

I thought being me was a liability to the dogist. And to a certain extent, it was. I was called odd, zany and even unprofessional for being open about my mental illness in New York. 

But it wasn’t only my lived experiences with serious mental illness stigma that contributed to my fear. It was also me and my thoughts that seeded the ever-growing fear that my being — my whole truth — wasn’t safe to exist out loud, if at all in business settings.

Intellectually, I know that I deserve to exist in this world.

Intellectually, I know that’s this community is incredible — that you are here to learn, support and dork out with me.

But emotionally, I am scared all the time.

I’m scared that anything I do might be weaponized as a reason that the doctors were right — that I do, in fact, only belong in a locked ward.

We have made so many strides in talking about mental health.

And yet, we have so much farther to go when it comes to mental illness, especially serious mental illness.

So yup, this is me, showing up in my fear this morning and saying I’m going to try to share the whole truth anyways.

I’m going to get messy and true and it’s going to be mighty uncomfortable for both of us.

But that discomfort — that is the currency of change. 

So today, from me and my discomfort to yours, I say, let’s with it. Let’s feel it. Let’s grow through it.

Heaven knows, it’s high time we did.

Share your willingness to help.

This world is not safe for people with mental illness. 

This world is also not safe for people to ask for help.

It is time to change the paradigm.

Instead of telling people to ask for help,

SHARE YOUR WILLINGNESS TO HELP.

This is the only way to save lives and this is where we begin to tackle the su1c1de epidemic head on.

Enough of the ‘new year, new you’ nonsense. We’re already enough, exactly as we are. Instead, here’s to a new year, FULLY OURSELVES.

Drop a 💜 below if you are ready to face your fears and heal your anxiety this year!!!!

 I sure am! I am so excited to be back with you all to finally share FEARS Camp in full!!!

FEARS is Face Everything and Rise Strategically.

This is the habit framework I have used over and over and over again in my life to build recovery habits. 

This recovery habit framework is how I went from being disabled, agoraphobic and destined to a long term psych ward to where I am now.

This framework is how I recovered from major depressive disorder. 
This framework is how I recovered from agoraphobia. 
And most profoundly, this framework is how I built a community.

FEARS Camp is a habit framework that empowers us to harness the discomfort of our life to grow us toward our goals.

Life is hard. That is just a fact.
And it’s actually not about it not being hard as much as we may wish it was.
Instead, it’s about that hardship serving our growth toward a life of meaning and joy — a life we want to live.

I am going to kick it off with nervous system regulation.
In order to harness discomfort to serve our growth and our goals, we have to also nourish these beautiful bodies and minds of ours after the stress of discomfort.

Then, in February, we will move into tolerating discomfort in the body. And thereafter, we will tackle exposures out in the world!

This is not one of these new year influencer challenges and this is certainly not a quick fix solution. This is the real world gut wrenching work of recovery. And, when we commit, it is a protocol that works.

So yup, I’m back in action and this is me stepping into alignment to become a public health educator that champions my own lived experience and the science that saved my life.

I am so excited to be here with you on this adventure. 

And whether you join me or not, please remember this:

I don’t presume to get your fight.
I don’t presume to get it at all.

AND

I see you in it.
And I wholeheartedly believe in us both.

Sending lots of love!
Kindly,
Kate

Drop a 💜 below if you love a good cry!

Now let’s take a nerdy nanosec to learn more about 

NERVOUS SYSTEM TECHNIQUE 1 — CRY IT OUT

Feeling is healing.

When we honor our feelings and accept them fully with radical kindness, we build a safe space for ourselves within ourselves. This is a huge part of nervous system regulation — building self-acceptance and safety into our environment.

The science of crying shows this as discussed in this excerpt from Harvard Medical School’s Health Blog:

“Crying allows us to release stress and emotional pain.

Crying is an important safety valve, largely because keeping difficult feelings inside — what psychologists call repressive coping — can be bad for our health. 

Studies have linked repressive coping with a less resilient immune system, cardiovascular disease, and hypertension, as well as with mental health conditions, including stress, anxiety, and depression.

Crying has also been shown to increase attachment behavior, encouraging closeness, empathy, and support from friends and family.

Scientists divide the liquid product of crying into three distinct categories: reflex tears, continuous tears, and emotional tears.

The first two categories perform the important function of removing debris such as smoke and dust from our eyes, and lubricating our eyes to help protect them from infection. Their content is 98% water.

It’s the third category, emotional tears (which flush stress hormones and other toxins out of our system), that potentially offers the most health benefits. 

Researchers have established that crying releases oxytocin and endogenous opioids, also known as endorphins.

These feel-good chemicals help ease both physical and emotional pain.”

To learn more, head to the l1nk 1n b1o where you can read the full article and explore the studies that evaluated the power of crying in the citations.

#nervoussystemregulation #anxiety #anxietyrecovery #anxietyrelief #seriousmentalillness

Holy Gratitude! I’m still processing the honor of this NPR piece. Ten years ago, I was destined to live out my days in a locked residential psychiatric ward, so to be here now is nothing short of surreal.

Since I have yet to find the words to adequately express this moment, I thought I’d borrow some today from my best friend, Maura:

The greatest gift we will ever know is to have someone here with us — in it — championing the truth that to live with mental illness is to live the greatest warriorhood one can ever know. 

And to have you,
Yes YOU,
here with me as I fight a mind hellbent on ending me,

It is a privilege I will never take lightly and one I will cherish until the end of time.

~

Yes, she definitely said it best. 

So today, in both gratitude for your presence here with me and disbelief that we have finally made it to a place where international news organizations celebrate serious mental illness advocacy, I invite you to join me on my next adventure in scaling public health campaigns and accessible mental health education.

If you, like me, want to:

- Further normalize serious mental illness 
- Get involved in upcoming public mental health campaigns to change state and federal policy 
- Learn more evidence-based information about mental health 
Please join me in my work with the Center for Health Communication at Harvard Chan School by doing these two things:

1. Follow their new account — @harvardchanchc  
2. Sign up to receive emails about upcoming public health campaigns to amplify and briefings about mental illness and mental health at the l1nk. 

I am so excited to see you there and be here with you as we build a better tomorrow for all of us.

Probably Anxious. Definitely grateful you’re here.
Normalizing serious mental illness recovery one messy, honest day at a time.
